div.p: Uttered to the confidante by HER when [he] delayed marriage.

lg.l: I, I am here. My innocence
with endless pain in the seashore grove.

The man from the ghat
in histuṟaivaṉ (sg.) + tam (pl.): how to understand this? He is not in their (i.e. his own people's) village (cf. 3b)? village. [is] in their village.
The secret become gossip of public places.

entry.def: end not-Traditionally āṉā is analysed as an obsolete adjective meaning "unending" (the TL contains just the two forms āṉā and āṉāmai). In fact, if one takes all the examples from the old anthologies together, we get large parts of a verbal paradigm, on the positive side complemented by another set of unexplained forms represented, in the KT, by āṉṟu, explained by TVG as irregular forms of akal, "to widen". My suggestion here is, after long discussions and in accordance with Jean-Luc Chevillard, to propose a verbal root °āṉ, "to end", (probably 3rd class), as the common basis for all these forms. Cf. also Rajam 1992, pp. 886-895 for her description of the verb āṉ, "to be content".

gramGrp.form: ēūrāṉ: in the whole Caṅkam literature only here and in PN 144.14 there is the long ā in the second syllable. The main reason certainly is to distinguish the usual pronominal noun from a real denominative as it is here (cf. nāṭṭar/nāṭaṉ). TVG attributes the long syllable to metrical requirements. Yet another possibility to be considered is -āṉ as a locative suffix, as is read by the old commentary on the PN passage ("the man from the ghat [is] in his village").

entry.def: village common itmaṉṟattaḵt’-ē: the form has to be explained as an oblique to maṉṟam + atu, n.sg. (i.e. predicate noun to maṟai), changed to aḵtu in front of the vowel -ē as sandhi demands it.
